name: Calderbank-Shor-Steane (CSS) stabilizer code
Linear binary code
Qubit code
Stabilizer code
Kitaev's surface code
My Test \(x:y\)-Code
alternative_names:
Funny Code
Bunny Code
Sunny Puny Tanny Dumby Rambly Code
description:
An \((n,2^k,d)\) linear code is denoted as \([n,k]\) or \([n,k,d]\), where \(d\) is the code's distance. Its codewords form a linear subspace, i.e., for any codewords \(x,y\), \(x+y\) is also a codeword. A code that is not linear is called nonlinear.

Linear codes can be defined in terms of a generator matrix \(G\), whose rows form a basis for the \(k\)-dimensional codespace. Given a message \(x\), the corresponding encoded codeword is \(G^T x\). The generator matrix can be reduced via coordinate permutations to its standard or systematic form \(G = [I_k~A]\), where \(I_k\) is a \(k\times k\) identity matrix and \(A\) is a \(k \times (n-k)\) binary matrix.
Encodes \(K\)-dimensional Hilbert space into a \(2^n\)-dimensional (i.e., \(n\)-qubit) Hilbert space. Usually denoted as \(((n,K))\) or \(((n,K,d))\), where \(d\) is the code's distance.

An \(((n,2^k,d))\) stabilizer code is denoted as \([[n,k]]\) or \([[n,k,d]]\), where \(d\) is the code's distance. Logical subspace is the joint \(+1\) eigenspace of a set of \(2^{n-k}\) commuting Pauli operators forming the code's stabilizer group. The distance is the minimum weight of a Pauli string that implements a nontrivial logical operation on the code.

A family of stabilizer codes whose generators are few-body \(X\)-type and \(Z\)-type Pauli strings associated to the stars and plaquettes, respectively, of a tessellation of a two-dimensional surface (with a qubit located at each edge of the tesselation). Toric code often either refers to the construction on the two-dimensional torus or is an alternative name for the general construction. The construction on surfaces with boundaries is often called the planar code [S. B. Bravyi and A. Yu. Kitaev, “Quantum codes on a lattice with boundary”, (1998) arXiv:quant-ph/9811052].

Here is the code's description. It can span multiple, hard-wrapped lines. It can include citations [V. V. Albert, J. P. Covey, and J. Preskill, “Robust Encoding of a Qubit in a Molecule”, Physical Review X 10, (2020) arXiv:1911.00099 DOI]. You can have math like \(a+b\) or \(\int_0^\infty f(x)\,dx\). You can also write \(\ket\psi = \sum_k \braket{e_k|\phi}\ket{e_k}\).

The description field can contain multiple paragraphs, like this. Each paragraph can contain formatted text, including hyperlinks and direct URLs: arxiv.org. The stabilizers are given in (3).

Have fun!!

Check this citation that doesn't resolve with crossref [A. M. Kubica, The ABCs of the Color Code: A Study of Topological Quantum Codes as Toy Models for Fault-Tolerant Quantum Computation and Quantum Phases Of Matter, California Institute of Technology, 2018 DOI].
features_code_capacity_threshold: Bounds on code capacity thresholds for various noise models exist in terms of stabilizer generator weights [A. A. Kovalev and L. P. Pryadko, “Fault tolerance of quantum low-density parity check codes with sublinear distance scaling”, Physical Review A 87, (2013) arXiv:1208.2317 DOI][I. Dumer, A. A. Kovalev, and L. P. Pryadko, “Thresholds for Correcting Errors, Erasures, and Faulty Syndrome Measurements in Degenerate Quantum Codes”, Physical Review Letters 115, (2015) arXiv:1412.6172 DOI].

\(10.9\%\) with independent \(X/Z\) errors for square tiling [M. Ohzeki, “Locations of multicritical points for spin glasses on regular lattices”, Physical Review E 79, (2009) arXiv:0811.0464 DOI].
\(18.9\%\) with depolarizing noise for square tiling [H. Bombin et al., “Strong Resilience of Topological Codes to Depolarization”, Physical Review X 2, (2012) arXiv:1202.1852 DOI].
features_decoders: Coherent decoders allow for measurement-free error correction [T. Inada et al., “Measurement-Free Ultrafast Quantum Error Correction by Using Multi-Controlled Gates in Higher-Dimensional State Space”, (2021) arXiv:2109.00086]. One method is table/multi-control decoding [G. A. Paz-Silva, G. K. Brennen, and J. Twamley, “Fault Tolerance with Noisy and Slow Measurements and Preparation”, Physical Review Letters 105, (2010) arXiv:1002.1536 DOI], which scales exponentially with the number of ancillas used in syndrome measurement. Another method, the Ising-based decoder, utilizes the mapping of the effect of the noise to a statistical mechanical model [E. Dennis et al., “Topological quantum memory”, Journal of Mathematical Physics 43, 4452 (2002) arXiv:quant-ph/0110143 DOI][A. T. Schmitz, “Thermal Stability of Dynamical Phase Transitions in Higher Dimensional Stabilizer Codes”, (2020) arXiv:2002.11733] such that the decoding problem maps to preparation of the ground state of an Ising model.

Decoding an arbitary linear binary code is NP-hard [E. Berlekamp, R. McEliece, and H. van Tilborg, “On the inherent intractability of certain coding problems (Corresp.)”, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory 24, 384 (1978) DOI].
Slepian's standard-array decoding [D. Slepian, “Some Further Theory of Group Codes”, Bell System Technical Journal 39, 1219 (1960) DOI].

Minimum weight perfect-matching [E. Dennis et al., “Topological quantum memory”, Journal of Mathematical Physics 43, 4452 (2002) arXiv:quant-ph/0110143 DOI][A. G. Fowler, “Minimum weight perfect matching of fault-tolerant topological quantum error correction in average O(1) parallel time”, Quantum Information and Computation 15, 145 (2015) DOI], union-find [N. Delfosse and N. H. Nickerson, “Almost-linear time decoding algorithm for topological codes”, Quantum 5, 595 (2021) arXiv:1709.06218 DOI], renormalization group [G. Duclos-Cianci and D. Poulin, “Fault-tolerant renormalization group decoder for abelian topological codes”, Quantum Information and Computation 14, 721 (2014) DOI][F. H. E. Watson, H. Anwar, and D. E. Browne, “Fast fault-tolerant decoder for qubit and qudit surface codes”, Physical Review A 92, (2015) arXiv:1411.3028 DOI], tensor network [S. Bravyi, M. Suchara, and A. Vargo, “Efficient algorithms for maximum likelihood decoding in the surface code”, Physical Review A 90, (2014) arXiv:1405.4883 DOI], Markov chain Monte Carlo [A. Hutter, J. R. Wootton, and D. Loss, “Efficient Markov chain Monte Carlo algorithm for the surface code”, Physical Review A 89, (2014) arXiv:1302.2669 DOI], cellular automaton [M. Herold et al., “Cellular automaton decoders of topological quantum memories in the fault tolerant setting”, New Journal of Physics 19, 063012 (2017) arXiv:1511.05579 DOI], machine learning [G. Torlai and R. G. Melko, “Neural Decoder for Topological Codes”, Physical Review Letters 119, (2017) arXiv:1610.04238 DOI][C. Chamberland and P. Ronagh, “Deep neural decoders for near term fault-tolerant experiments”, Quantum Science and Technology 3, 044002 (2018) arXiv:1802.06441 DOI][R. Sweke et al., “Reinforcement learning decoders for fault-tolerant quantum computation”, Machine Learning: Science and Technology 2, 025005 (2020) arXiv:1810.07207 DOI].
features_encoders: Stabilizer measurement [J. Łodyga et al., “Simple scheme for encoding and decoding a qubit in unknown state for various topological codes”, Scientific Reports 5, (2015) arXiv:1404.2495 DOI].

Dissipative preparation, for which codespace is steady-state space of a Lindbladian [J. Dengis, R. König, and F. Pastawski, “An optimal dissipative encoder for the toric code”, New Journal of Physics 16, 013023 (2014) arXiv:1310.1036 DOI].

Unitary [M. Aguado and G. Vidal, “Entanglement Renormalization and Topological Order”, Physical Review Letters 100, (2008) arXiv:0712.0348 DOI][O. Higgott et al., “Optimal local unitary encoding circuits for the surface code”, Quantum 5, 517 (2021) arXiv:2002.00362 DOI][Y.-J. Liu et al., “Methods for Simulating String-Net States and Anyons on a Digital Quantum Computer”, PRX Quantum 3, (2022) arXiv:2110.02020 DOI].
Dissipative [J. Dengis, R. König, and F. Pastawski, “An optimal dissipative encoder for the toric code”, New Journal of Physics 16, 013023 (2014) arXiv:1310.1036 DOI].
Stabilizer measurement-based [J. Łodyga et al., “Simple scheme for encoding and decoding a qubit in unknown state for various topological codes”, Scientific Reports 5, (2015) arXiv:1404.2495 DOI].
features_fault_tolerance:
Steane error correction [A. M. Steane, “Active Stabilization, Quantum Computation, and Quantum State Synthesis”, Physical Review Letters 78, 2252 (1997) arXiv:quant-ph/9611027 DOI].
Parallel syndrome extraction for distance-three codes can be done fault-tolerantly using one flag qubit [P.-H. Liou and C.-Y. Lai, “Parallel syndrome extraction with shared flag qubits for Calderbank-Shor-Steane codes of distance three”, Physical Review A 107, (2023) arXiv:2208.00581 DOI].
features_general_gates: LDPC CSS code symmetries called \(XZ\)-dualities allow for fold-transversal gates, i.e., transversal gates followed by qubit permutations [N. P. Breuckmann and S. Burton, “Fold-Transversal Clifford Gates for Quantum Codes”, (2022) arXiv:2202.06647].

Clifford gates can be implemented via lattice surgery [D. Horsman et al., “Surface code quantum computing by lattice surgery”, New Journal of Physics 14, 123011 (2012) arXiv:1111.4022 DOI][D. Litinski and F. von Oppen, “Lattice Surgery with a Twist: Simplifying Clifford Gates of Surface Codes”, Quantum 2, 62 (2018) arXiv:1709.02318 DOI] or braiding defects [R. Raussendorf and J. Harrington, “Fault-Tolerant Quantum Computation with High Threshold in Two Dimensions”, Physical Review Letters 98, (2007) arXiv:quant-ph/0610082 DOI][R. Raussendorf, J. Harrington, and K. Goyal, “Topological fault-tolerance in cluster state quantum computation”, New Journal of Physics 9, 199 (2007) arXiv:quant-ph/0703143 DOI][A. G. Fowler et al., “Surface codes: Towards practical large-scale quantum computation”, Physical Review A 86, (2012) arXiv:1208.0928 DOI][B. J. Brown et al., “Poking Holes and Cutting Corners to Achieve Clifford Gates with the Surface Code”, Physical Review X 7, (2017) arXiv:1609.04673 DOI].
Non-Clifford gates require magic state distillation [D. Litinski, “Magic State Distillation: Not as Costly as You Think”, Quantum 3, 205 (2019) arXiv:1905.06903 DOI] or just-in-time decoding [B. J. Brown, “A fault-tolerant non-Clifford gate for the surface code in two dimensions”, Science Advances 6, (2020) arXiv:1903.11634 DOI].
features_rate: For a depolarizing channel with probability \(p\), CSS codes allowing for arbitrarily accurate recovery exist with asymptotic rate \(1-2h(p)\), where \(h\) is the binary entropy function [E. Dennis et al., “Topological quantum memory”, Journal of Mathematical Physics 43, 4452 (2002) arXiv:quant-ph/0110143 DOI].
A family of linear codes \(C_i = [n_i,k_i,d_i]\) is asymptotically good if the asymptotic rate \(\lim_{i\to\infty} k_i/n_i\) and asymptotic distance \(\lim_{i\to\infty} d_i/n_i\) are both positive.
features_threshold:
\(10.9\%\) with independent \(X/Z\) errors for square tiling [M. Ohzeki, “Locations of multicritical points for spin glasses on regular lattices”, Physical Review E 79, (2009) arXiv:0811.0464 DOI].
\(18.9\%\) with depolarizing noise for square tiling [H. Bombin et al., “Strong Resilience of Topological Codes to Depolarization”, Physical Review X 2, (2012) arXiv:1202.1852 DOI].
\(50\%\) with loss errors for square tiling [T. M. Stace, S. D. Barrett, and A. C. Doherty, “Thresholds for Topological Codes in the Presence of Loss”, Physical Review Letters 102, (2009) arXiv:0904.3556 DOI].
\(3.3\%\) with phenomenological noise for square tiling [T. Ohno et al., “Phase structure of the random-plaquette gauge model: accuracy threshold for a toric quantum memory”, Nuclear Physics B 697, 462 (2004) arXiv:quant-ph/0401101 DOI].
\(0.5-1.1\%\) for various error models [A. M. Stephens, “Fault-tolerant thresholds for quantum error correction with the surface code”, Physical Review A 89, (2014) arXiv:1311.5003 DOI].
features_transversal_gates: CNOT gates. Self-dual CSS codes admit transversal Clifford gates.
introduced: [A. M. Steane, “Error Correcting Codes in Quantum Theory”, Physical Review Letters 77, 793 (1996) DOI][“Multiple-particle interference and quantum error correction”, Proceedings of the Royal Society of London. Series A: Mathematical, Physical and Engineering Sciences 452, 2551 (1996) arXiv:quant-ph/9601029 DOI][A. R. Calderbank and P. W. Shor, “Good quantum error-correcting codes exist”, Physical Review A 54, 1098 (1996) arXiv:quant-ph/9512032 DOI; hello]
[D. Gottesman, “Stabilizer Codes and Quantum Error Correction”, (1997) arXiv:quant-ph/9705052]

[A. Yu. Kitaev, “Quantum Error Correction with Imperfect Gates”, Quantum Communication, Computing, and Measurement 181 (1997) DOI][A. Yu. Kitaev, “Fault-tolerant quantum computation by anyons”, Annals of Physics 303, 2 (2003) arXiv:quant-ph/9707021 DOI]
[V. V. Albert, J. P. Covey, and J. Preskill, “Robust Encoding of a Qubit in a Molecule”, Physical Review X 10, (2020) arXiv:1911.00099 DOI]
notes:
Introduction to CSS-to-homology correspondence by M. Hastings.
Using linear programming to solve a set of equations and inequalities on weight distribution of a classical self-orthogonal code \(C=(n, 2^n-k)\) and its dual, one can find a \(C\) such that the \([[n,k,d]]\) CSS code constructed using \(C\) and its dual would have rate and distance close to the Singleton bound [A. R. Calderbank et al., “Quantum Error Correction via Codes over GF(4)”, (1997) arXiv:quant-ph/9608006].
Original requirement of \(C_1^\perp \subset C_2\) [A. R. Calderbank and P. W. Shor, “Good quantum error-correcting codes exist”, Physical Review A 54, 1098 (1996) arXiv:quant-ph/9512032 DOI] has been relaxed to absorb hypergraph product codes.

Tables of bounds and examples of linear codes for various \(n\) and \(k\), extending code tables by A. E. Brouwer [Andries E. Brouwer, Bounds on linear codes, in: Vera S. Pless and W. Cary Huffman (Eds.), Handbook of Coding Theory, pp. 295-461, Elsevier, 1998.], are maintained by M. Grassl at this website.
Toric code introductions from error-correction perspective by J. Haah and condensed-matter perspective by M. Levin and C. Nayak.

A second note goes here. This one contains a display equation: \begin{align}
  S_1 &= I\,Z\,X\,X\,Z\ ;  \nonumber\\
  S_2, \ldots, S_4 &= \text{cyclical permutations of \(S_1\)}\ .
  \label{eq:stabilizers}
\tag*{(3)}\end{align} Note that the last cyclical permutation of \(S_1\) is not included, as it is given by \(S_1S_2S_3S_4\).

Yeah!

protection:
Detects errors on \(d-1\) qubits, corrects errors on \(\left\lfloor (d-1)/2 \right\rfloor\) qubits.

Using the relation to chain complexes, the number of encoded logical qubits is equal to the dimension of the first \(\mathbb{Z}_2\)-homology of the chain complex, \(H_1(\partial, \mathbb{Z}_2) = \frac{\text{Ker}(\partial_1)}{\text{Im}(\partial_2)}\). The distance of the CSS code is equal to the minimum of the combinatorial (\(d-1\))-systole of the cellulated \(d\)-dimensional manifold and its dual.

Distance \(d\) of a linear code is the number of nonzero entries in the (nonzero) codeword with the smallest such number. Corrects any error set for which no two elements of the set add up to a codeword.

Linear codes admit a parity check matrix \(H\), whose columns make up a set of parity checks, i.e., a maximal linearly independent set of vectors that are in the kernel of \(G\). It follows that \begin{align}
  G H^{\text{T}} = 0 \mod 2~.
\tag*{(1)}\end{align}

Detects errors on up to \(d-1\) qubits, and corrects erasure errors on up to \(d-1\) qubits.

When defined on an \(L\times L\) square tiling of the torus, protects against \(L\) errors. More generally, the code distance is related to the homology of the tessellation [E. Dennis et al., “Topological quantum memory”, Journal of Mathematical Physics 43, 4452 (2002) arXiv:quant-ph/0110143 DOI].

Detects errors on \(d-1\) qubits, corrects errors on \(\left\lfloor (d-1)/2
\right\rfloor\) qubits.

We can use definition environments, too:

Knill-Laflamme conditions: In a finite-dimensional Hilbert space, there are necessary and sufficient conditions for a code to successfully correct a set of errors. These are called the Knill-Laflamme conditions [E. Knill, R. Laflamme, and L. Viola, “Theory of Quantum Error Correction for General Noise”, Physical Review Letters 84, 2525 (2000) arXiv:quant-ph/9604034 DOI][J. Preskill. Lecture notes on Quantum Computation. (1997–2020) URL][M. A. Nielsen and I. L. Chuang, Quantum Computation and Quantum Information (Cambridge University Press, 2012) DOI; Thm. 10.1]. A code defined by a partial isometry \(U\) with code space projector \(\Pi = U U^\dagger\) can correct a set of errors \(\{ E_j \}\) if and only if \begin{align}
    \Pi E_i^\dagger E_j \Pi = c_{ij}\, \Pi\qquad\text{for all \(i,j\),}
  \tag*{(1)}\end{align} where \(c_{ij}\) can be arbitrary numbers.
realizations:
Fully homomorphic encryption [G. Alagic et al., “Quantum Fully Homomorphic Encryption with Verification”, Advances in Cryptology – ASIACRYPT 2017 438 (2017) arXiv:1708.09156 DOI].
Entanglement purification protocols related to quantum key distribution (QKD) [P. W. Shor and J. Preskill, “Simple Proof of Security of the BB84 Quantum Key Distribution Protocol”, Physical Review Letters 85, 441 (2000) arXiv:quant-ph/0003004 DOI].

Distance-two surface codes have been implemented by Andersen et al. [C. K. Andersen et al., “Repeated quantum error detection in a surface code”, Nature Physics 16, 875 (2020) arXiv:1912.09410 DOI], Erhard et al. [A. Erhard et al., “Entangling logical qubits with lattice surgery”, Nature 589, 220 (2021) arXiv:2006.03071 DOI] and Google Quantum AI [“Exponential suppression of bit or phase errors with cyclic error correction”, Nature 595, 383 (2021) DOI].
relations_cousins_detail: Construction uses two related binary linear codes.
relations_parents_detail: Stabilizer generators can be expressed as either only \(X\)-type or only \(Z\)-type.
Plaquette and star operators are stabilizer generators.

Description of how this code relates to stabilizer codes.[X. Zhou et al., “Resistivity saturation in a weakly interacting two-dimensional Fermi liquid at intermediate temperatures”, Physical Review B 85, (2012) arXiv:1111.0011 DOI]
